thread.title: I’m A Celebrity 2017: Crocodile fears hit camp
thread.title_full: I’m A Celebrity 2017: Crocodile fears hit camp | Daily Telegraph

author: Jonathon Moran
title: I’m A Celebrity 2017: Crocodile fears hit camp
text:
I’m A Celeb: Tegan in tears after zebra attack I’m A Celeb: Nazeem - Pauline Hanson ‘is helping ISIS’ FLOODING has caused parts of the I’m A Celebrity … Get Me Out Of Here! production to be disrupted.
Rising waters of around three metres on the banks of the Blyde River near Kruger National Park have caused the Tucker Trial area of the Channel Ten reality show to be evacuated.
“The rainfall has hit us really hard,” safety consultant Paul ‘Risky’ Chivers told News Corp.
“Obviously it has flooded the set here and now we are concerned about crocodiles coming down the river and also hippos tend to come in to the side of the rapids and hide.”
media_camera Rainfall has hit really hard. Picture: Supplied.
On Thursday production was put on notice as Cyclone Dineo made its way from Mozambique into South Africa with wind speeds of more than 120kmh.
Flash flooding is the biggest risk to production with contingency plans in place to evacuate celebrities in camp should the water continue to rise.
THE RIGHT DIET: Tziporah Malkah ‘must lose’ 20kg
media_camera Flooding hits the set of I'm A Celebrity ... Get Me Out Of Here! Picture: Nigel Wright/Ten
Celebrities are usually allowed to visit the nearby waterfall, although this area has also been cordoned off due to the increased water flow.
“They would be moved to the Tok Tokki and from there we would move them out to higher ground,” Chivers said of the evacuation plan. “We have to just play it by ear as the water rises, then we will put the procedures in place and the controls we have into action.”
media_camera Flash flooding is the biggest risk to production. Picture: Supplied.
With the trials area off limits, the Tuesday Tucker Trial will now be filmed in the tree house studio where Julia Morris and Chris Brown host the daily show.
It is the first time a trial has been filmed in the studio over the show’s three series.
“We chose this location with the full knowledge that it was prone to flooding and therefore have contingency plans and alternate locations in place ready to go,” Network Ten head of entertainment and factual Stephen Tate said.
media_camera The location is prone to flooding. Picture: Supplied.
“The upside to the flooding is that it also creates our beautiful jungle.”
Production receives weather information from the local disaster management team, the local air force base and weather forecasters on a minute to minute basis.
media_camera Cyclone Dineo has caused flooding on the set of I'm A Celebrity ... Get Me Out Of Here!
A crew of more than 420 people work around the clock on the show, from the contestants to editors, camera crews and producers.
It is in stark contrast to last years’s series when the local dam was not flowing at all.
“We are expecting more rain over the coming week but we have a great team who can escalate our controls into place really quickly if something happens,” Chivers explained.
In 2012, the Limpopo Provence, where the show is filmed, registered its worst flooding on record with more than 700mm of rainfall in a 24 hour period and townships cut off completely.
No fatalities were recorded but more than 600 homes were destroyed and some towns were without drinking water for more than a month.
* The journalist is in South Africa as a guest of Channel Ten.
 Crocodile fears hits camp Celebrity
